channel.title: Moparclassic vs Rscangel based sources
channel.description:
Can someone (in detail) please explain exactly why Moparclassic is a better base to build off of as compared to Rsca? People have told me it is because Rsca has many exploits, but is that the only reason? If so, what are the exploits and why cant they easily be fixed?
On another note: Also, I noticed that Moparclassic had all of Rsca's custom content removed, is there a way to put it back in? Finally, can someone tell me how to base the commandhandler off java format instead of scala? Thank you :)

item.title: Moparclassic vs Rscangel based sources
item.description:
@5_1 wrote:

Basically, MoparClassic is made from RSCAngel source. So why go back on an old source when you can use an up-to date one?

TL;DR : Mopar = RSCAngel < Mopar

Read full topic

item.title: Moparclassic vs Rscangel based sources
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“waj, post:12, topic:453017”]Forgot to check this.

And not bad Edward, it sure seems different but it seems like the java command(in this case) could be easily converted just by looking at the current commands which exist, non the less it seems a hell of a lot cleaner than them ugly command handlers that have been used for so many years.[/quote]Most of the code for the commands themselves were copy & pasted from the Java version. There were minor changes (such as removing the type and putting val/var).

I believe some were completely re-written, but for the most part, the commands themselves are nearly identical to their Java counterparts.

Read full topic

item.title: Moparclassic vs Rscangel based sources
item.dc:creator: @Wife_Beater Wife Beater
item.description:
@Wife_Beater wrote:

[quote=“CodeForFame, post:10, topic:453017”][quote author=waj link=topic=555873.msg4070146#msg4070146 date=1344274419]
How are the commands handled now?

Just curious, will check later when on the computer if no-one sheds any light on how there handled.
[/quote]Previously there was a huge mess of if statements. Then, to make it even messier, in the single method, you had to make sure you put it in the right place, to ensure the user had proper permissions.

Now, permissions are in a configuration file, and commands are matched to the proper function.

Let’s look a command to see what else is different…

Before:

static String[] towns = { "varrock", "falador", "draynor", "portsarim", "karamja", "alkharid", "lumbridge", "edgeville", "castle" }; static Point[] townLocations = { Point.location(122, 509), Point.location(304, 542), Point.location(214, 632), Point.location(269, 643), Point.location(370, 685), Point.location(89, 693), Point.location(120, 648), Point.location(217, 449), Point.location(270, 352) };

if (cmd.equalsIgnoreCase("town")) { try { String town = args[0]; if (town != null) { for (int i = 0; i < towns.length; i++) if (town.equalsIgnoreCase(towns[i])) { player.teleport(townLocations[i].getX(), townLocations[i].getY(), false); return; } } } catch (Exception e) { e.printStackTrace(); } }
And that needed to be placed between the check for the player being a pmod and being a mod.

Now:

val towns = List[(String, Point)]( ("varrock", Point.location(122, 509)), ("falador", Point.location(304, 542)), ("draynor", Point.location(214, 632)), ("portsarim", Point.location(269, 643)), ("karamja", Point.location(370, 685)), ("alkharid", Point.location(89, 693)), ("lumbridge", Point.location(120, 648)), ("edgeville", Point.location(217, 449)), ("castle", Point.location(270, 352)) )

<!-- Teleports the player to the specified town --> <permission name="town">1</permission>

def town(p : Player, args : Array[String]) { val town = args(0); CH.towns.find(e => e._1 equalsIgnoreCase town) match { case Some(x) => p.teleport(x._2.getX, x._2.getY, false) case None => } }

Now, let’s look at what has been improved or is different…

Lines of code wise, the new version is smaller (if you properly format the Java code), even if you include the XML that is required to set the permissions level.
Where you put the method doesn’t matter anymore.
We don’t have to explicitly loop through all the towns; we simply say, find me a town that matches.
We don’t have to worry about ordering of towns and their locations, along with making sure there is a matching pair.
We don’t have to worry about catching exceptions, but we can if we want to.
We don’t have to have guards making sure things aren’t null.
We can easily change who has access to the command, and we don’t even need to re-compile or change any code.
Our mapping of towns to locations is now immutable.
We don’t have to make sure we jump out of the method (calling return at the end) to make sure other commands won’t be executed and additional conditions won’t be checked.

Because of these changes, the Scala version is much more readable, even if you don’t know how to program it isn’t hard to figure out what’s going on. The same really can’t be said for the Java version.

[quote author=Wife Beater link=topic=555873.msg4070195#msg4070195 date=1344279347]

How are the commands handled now?

Just curious, will check later when on the computer if no-one sheds any light on how there handled.

they use scala format now, and have a seperate permissions class that lets certain ranks use them
[/quote]No, it’s still all contained in the same class, even though it shouldn’t be (I kept it simple so it wouldn’t be such a huge leap).

Permissions aren’t hard-coded or based on the position a command is in some monolithic method.

P.S. If you want to compare old to new, here are the links:
Old (I should mention that it’s missing several commands): https://github.com/Lothy/MoparClassic/blob/10f4d9c876debe3ed5f18911da5e940e5abc77a1/GameServer/src/msc/gs/phandler/client/CommandHandler.java
New: https://github.com/Lothy/MoparClassic/blob/pre-beta/GameServer/src/org/moparscape/msc/gs/phandler/client/CommandHandler.scala[/quote]

Good answer, u may of convinced me

Read full topic

item.title: Moparclassic vs Rscangel based sources
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“waj, post:8, topic:453017”]How are the commands handled now?

Just curious, will check later when on the computer if no-one sheds any light on how there handled.[/quote]Previously there was a huge mess of if statements. Then, to make it even messier, in the single method, you had to make sure you put it in the right place, to ensure the user had proper permissions.

Now, permissions are in a configuration file, and commands are matched to the proper function.

Let’s look a command to see what else is different…

Before:

static String[] towns = { "varrock", "falador", "draynor", "portsarim", "karamja", "alkharid", "lumbridge", "edgeville", "castle" }; static Point[] townLocations = { Point.location(122, 509), Point.location(304, 542), Point.location(214, 632), Point.location(269, 643), Point.location(370, 685), Point.location(89, 693), Point.location(120, 648), Point.location(217, 449), Point.location(270, 352) };

if (cmd.equalsIgnoreCase("town")) { try { String town = args[0]; if (town != null) { for (int i = 0; i < towns.length; i++) if (town.equalsIgnoreCase(towns[i])) { player.teleport(townLocations[i].getX(), townLocations[i].getY(), false); return; } } } catch (Exception e) { e.printStackTrace(); } }
And that needed to be placed between the check for the player being a pmod and being a mod.

Now:

val towns = List[(String, Point)]( ("varrock", Point.location(122, 509)), ("falador", Point.location(304, 542)), ("draynor", Point.location(214, 632)), ("portsarim", Point.location(269, 643)), ("karamja", Point.location(370, 685)), ("alkharid", Point.location(89, 693)), ("lumbridge", Point.location(120, 648)), ("edgeville", Point.location(217, 449)), ("castle", Point.location(270, 352)) )

<!-- Teleports the player to the specified town --> <permission name="town">1</permission>

def town(p : Player, args : Array[String]) { val town = args(0); CH.towns.find(e => e._1 equalsIgnoreCase town) match { case Some(x) => p.teleport(x._2.getX, x._2.getY, false) case None => } }

Now, let’s look at what has been improved or is different…

Lines of code wise, the new version is smaller (if you properly format the Java code), even if you include the XML that is required to set the permissions level.
Where you put the method doesn’t matter anymore.
We don’t have to explicitly loop through all the towns; we simply say, find me a town that matches.
We don’t have to worry about ordering of towns and their locations, along with making sure there is a matching pair.
We don’t have to worry about catching exceptions, but we can if we want to.
We don’t have to have guards making sure things aren’t null.
We can easily change who has access to the command, and we don’t even need to re-compile or change any code.
Our mapping of towns to locations is now immutable.
We don’t have to make sure we jump out of the method (calling return at the end) to make sure other commands won’t be executed and additional conditions won’t be checked.

Because of these changes, the Scala version is much more readable, even if you don’t know how to program it isn’t hard to figure out what’s going on. The same really can’t be said for the Java version.

[quote=“Wife Beater, post:9, topic:453017”][quote author=waj link=topic=555873.msg4070146#msg4070146 date=1344274419]
How are the commands handled now?

Just curious, will check later when on the computer if no-one sheds any light on how there handled.
[/quote]

they use scala format now, and have a seperate permissions class that lets certain ranks use them[/quote]No, it’s still all contained in the same class, even though it shouldn’t be (I kept it simple so it wouldn’t be such a huge leap).

Permissions aren’t hard-coded or based on the position a command is in some monolithic method.

P.S. If you want to compare old to new, here are the links:
Old (I should mention that it’s missing several commands): https://github.com/Lothy/MoparClassic/blob/10f4d9c876debe3ed5f18911da5e940e5abc77a1/GameServer/src/msc/gs/phandler/client/CommandHandler.java
New: https://github.com/Lothy/MoparClassic/blob/pre-beta/GameServer/src/org/moparscape/msc/gs/phandler/client/CommandHandler.scala

Read full topic

item.title: Moparclassic vs Rscangel based sources
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

There is absolutely no reason to go back to the shitty way commands were handled before.

Also, if you can’t figure out how to replace a class, then you have no business working on a server.

Read full topic

item.title: Moparclassic vs Rscangel based sources
item.dc:creator: @ChaosPkers ChaosPkers
item.description:
@ChaosPkers wrote:

Moparclassic has the word mopar in it, therefore it is better.
Jk, it’s because Moparclassic is a ton cleaner, for sure.

It’s not hard at all to add the RSCA content back. If you had ANY Java knowledge you could do it, and you wouldn’t need to be spoonfed of everything.
[/quote]

I refreshed the page and saw that -nothing posted, im like shit. its probably just a shit comment. And hey i was right[/quote]
My post was a fact. Nothing else.

Read full topic

item.description:

If I’m not mistaken, Moparclassic source IS the RSCAngel source… Just with most of the bug fixes and most of the exploit fixes… Also cleaned up a lot
